posts.name: jhajel
posts.cooked:
We are looking for a source to get 36x36" 1/8 and 3/16 polycarbonate.  The best we could find is McMaster for $86 for the 3/16" thick and 53" for the 1/8".

Thanks so much.

JMH
We use E Street Plastics. They have a good variety of thickness and colors of PC

posts.name: Mike Marandola
posts.cooked: We bought 4’ x 8’ sheets this year from Curbell Plastics and had them pre-cut them. Way cheaper than buying from McMaster. Great company to work with

posts.name: Justin | 6925 Alumentor
posts.cooked: We bought the Clear Impact-Resistant Polycarbonate, 24" x 36" x 1/4" Sheet from McMaster this year and were very pleased with the results. It is a little pricey but we thought it was definitely worth it.

posts.name: jedgar6
posts.cooked: We order off of amazon often because a lot of polycarb is .23 not .25. However, another source is  plastic companies have scrap piles. Basically they take you to a dumpster and you can pick out scraps. We got almost 100lbs of plastic in one visit.

posts.name: JamesCH95
posts.cooked: Whatever your local supplier is. I use Polymer Shapes for my side business. Can be 1/4 the price of McMaster.

posts.name: s-neff
posts.cooked:
Can you handle 4x8? Does it need to get mailed or can you pick it up?

We go to Tap Plastic, who can do custom cuts, when we’re in a hurry to pick something up.

There’s Also a couple larger suppliers out of San Jose if you can pick up from down there. @AdamHeard might have a favorite too.

If you need it mailed to you yes McMaster…

posts.name: Jerry Krist - Lead Mentor FRC Team 1792
posts.cooked: Look for a local plastic or sign company.
posts.display_username: Jerry Krist - Lead Mentor FRC Team 1792

posts.cooked: Most of us find local sources for plastic—not sure who is the best in the Bay Area. Around here we use Cope Plastics.

posts.name: Liu
posts.cooked: I would look for old covid shields. Government building are trying to get rid of them. We got quite a few which were 36” x 36” 1/4 polycarb for almost nothing.

posts.name: snoman
posts.cooked:
Most of the ones we got around here for covid guards is acrylic and you don’t want to use that.

Our local glass shop stocks polycarbonate $320 for a 4x8 sheet of quarter inch and $190 for eighth inch

posts.name: Totally out of touch
posts.cooked: @Cory knows local better than me, but I’ve bought from both Port and Tap locally. It’s not drastically cheaper than mcmaster, but being able to pickup w/o paying shipping saves a lot on the bigger pieces.

posts.name: Liu
posts.cooked: Don’t be so sure, we thought the same thing but we when we went out to look at it everything was polycarb.

posts.name: Alex Lu
posts.cooked: SoCal here, we use Professional Plastics, pretty affordable sheets, a 2 by 4 3/16 usually is 40 ish bucks, but they once had a pretty long period of $20 for that specific size and thickness. Their scrap piles also offer us small pieces for anything non-sheet.

posts.name: Cory
posts.cooked:
I don’t know the per piece breakdown but we got 3 sheets of 1/8 and 3 sheets of 1/4 from Port Plastics for the field this year and spent $1425. I would assume that’s roughly $300/sheet of 1/4 and $150/sheet of 1/8, which would be a little cheaper than McMaster but way cheaper compared to shipping McMaster.

TAP plastics is ok for small bits of plastic, but their whole sheet pricing wasn’t competitive when we stopped using them 10+ years ago. Haven’t checked back with them but I assume that hasn’t changed.

posts.name: Max Morehead
posts.cooked: Tap is much more expensive than Mcmaster when not considering shipping and only slightly better or a wash when considering shipping. They are good for small amounts, though, especially given they are 2 minutes from our school. Plus they’ve let us grab free off cuts in the past (YMMV).

posts.name: Anand Rajamani
posts.cooked:
Last I checked, Port Plastics was about 30% cheaper than McMaster before shipping, and 60-70% cheaper after shipping. TAP is about 2-4x the price of Port.

If you live in the SF bay area I cannot recommend Port highly enough. They are great at getting plastics for you and if you ask nicely they will cut it into 2x3 sheets for you. 4x4 is the minimum order but that’s less than most teams can use in a season just on intake plates, and it’s cheap anyway.

The one downside is that their smoked polycarb is only somewhat grey and not very dark.

posts.name: Technologyman00
posts.cooked: Andymark has very reasonable prices 24 in. x 24 in. Polycarbonate Sheets - AndyMark, Inc .

link_counts.title: 24 in. x 24 in. Polycarbonate Sheets - AndyMark, Inc

posts.name: Kyle Swaidner
posts.cooked: If you don’t mind dealing with an odd thickness of 0.177" you can get 4’x8’ sheets at your local Home Depot for ~$190.  I thought that price was excessive but seems inline with most other suppliers that people are mentioning.

posts.name: Zach
posts.cooked: It has already been mentioned but more specifically, university surplus stores. We bought a roughly 5’ x 8’ rolling COVID shield from Purdue for $20. Cheap 1x1 tubing for a frame and the plastic was some kind of acrylic. I am currently using it as a shield to keep aluminum chips contained around our cnc.  I have also thought about making it a mobile drive station.
